content.question: Which of the following explains the connections between <math alttext="I M F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IMF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> policy and Mexico’s relationship with supranational organizations?

choices.label: The <math alttext="I M F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IMF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> required Mexico to join the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (<math alttext="O E C D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>OECD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) before Mexico could be granted economic assistance.

The imposition of tariffs by the <math alttext="I M F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IMF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> meant that Mexico’s application to join the North American Free Trade Agreement (<math alttext="NAFTA" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NAFTA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) was denied.

The economic liberalization policies introduced by the <math alttext="I M F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IMF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> facilitated Mexico’s integration into <math alttext="NAFTA" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NAFTA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
Mexico refused to join any supranational organization, afraid that it would lead to a loss of state sovereignty.

content.answer: The economic liberalization policies introduced by the <math alttext="I M F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IMF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> facilitated Mexico’s integration into <math alttext="NAFTA" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NAFTA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
